instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PM_BATLOW: What is PM_BATLOW? PM_BATLOW is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on.
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: 820-000164 No power
threads.message:
Hi, have an 820-000164 here ive been scratching my head over. 

The bios area had corrosion so i replaced a couple of resistors and the SPI chip, finely got it posting and running gave it to my tech to test, he said that the keyboard and mouse only worked in OSX, he did a pram reset and now the machine is stuck in S5 with no SUS EN <SIGNAL>DSW_PWRDGD</SIGNAL> is present <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW</SIGNAL> is present, im getting real confused.

threads.title: 820-000164 No power
threads.message: Then SMC should generate <SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. Suspecting crap under SMC. Is PPBUS at 12.56V?

threads.title: 820-000164 No power
threads.message: sorry, that is present, <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is only 30ohm to ground which seems all wrong, removed allsorts on that rail and not had any resistance change.any ideas?

threads.title: 820-000164 No power
threads.message: 30 ohm short will be hard to track down. You can try heat/cool areas of the board and see if the resistance changes.

threads.title: 820-000164 No power
threads.message:
Ive already tried the heat method and strangely enough i didnt get anywhere- usually it is fantastic. Ive ran round the schematic on the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> line checking everything its connected too. theres  no other rails that could cause it thats connected via a 32ohm resistor unfortunately.

Ive removed all Active chips apart from the PCH (for obvious reasons on these boards)
Ive removed some of the passive components however its super rare that capacitors would go 30ohm short. 

Thinking im digging too deep and should give up.
Got any final ideas?

threads.title: 820-000164 No power
threads.message: CPU/PCH would be a prime suspect, so yeah probably the end.

threads.title: 820-000164 No power
threads.message:
Yeah thats what im thinking, it also booted once with no keyboard and mouse and as said failed after PRAM reset which all ties together to created a good suspicion.
You ever had any success reworking these things, Every time i pull a CPU of a donor board i get mega chip flex, ive managed to get one replace once but the victory was shortlived. New chips are stupid expensive too. :/

threads.title: 820-000164 No power
threads.message: Nah, I don't bother replacing the CPUs. Too much risk
